questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with colicky abdominal pain and fever had multiple GB calculi measuring 1.5cm. No dilatation of CBD noted. She was planned for Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy. Which of the following is not a feature of minimal access surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Good tactile sense Good tactile sense is not a feature of minimal access surgery rather, the tactile sense is decreased, which is a disadvantage of MAS.

Highyeild:

Minimal Access Surgery (MAS): It involves performing surgery through small incisions Includes laparoscopy, thoracoscopy, endoluminal endoscopy, perivisceral endoscopy, arthroscopy, and intra-articular joint surgery Advantages of MAS: Decrease in wound size Reduction in wound infection, dehiscence, bleeding, herniation, and nerve entrapment Decrease in wound pain Improved mobility Decreased wound trauma Decreased heat loss Improved vision Faster recovery and shorter hospital stay

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & D. Are advantages of Minimal access surgery. Advantages of Minimal access surgery: Wound size small Reduced incidence of Wound infection and Gaping Reduced pain in the post-op period Improved mobility after surgery Decreased wound trauma Decreased heat loss Improved Vision

Extraedge:

Minimal access surgery has limitations. Advances in instrumentation and endoscopic systems have addressed some of these limitations, but the basic principles remain the same. The use of surgical robots can address some of these limitations. However, surgical robots also present new challenges.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female with a known history of gallstones presented complaints of two days of right upper quadrant pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. Was she diagnosed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calculous Cholecystitis Acute cholecystitis, or gallbladder infection, is associated with gallstones in 90% to 95% of cases. A gallstone's obstruction of the cystic duct is the initiating event that leads to gallbladder enlargement, inflammation, and edema of the gallbladder wall. TOC is lap. Cholecystectomy.

Highyeild:

Calculous Cholecystitis It is a condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder caused by gallstones . The gallstones obstruct the cystic duct, leading to stasis of bile within the gallbladder, and this can cause inflammation, ischemia, and infection . The inflammation may cause complications such as biliary colic, obstructive jaundice, cholangitis, or pancreatitis. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging studies, such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI, which show the gallstones and signs of inflammation. The treatment of choice is laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which involves the removal of the gallbladder. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment, the prognosis for calculous cholecystitis is generally favorable.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Blockage of the cystic duct in the absence of stones is called acalculous cholecystitis. Option: C. In < 1% of acute cholecystitis, the cause is a tumor obstructing the cystic duct. Option: D. Calculous cholecystitis develops when the cystic duct gets blocked by a gallstone. In Asia, 80% of gallstones are pigment stones.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man residing in Delhi complained of abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound indicated acute cholecystitis and a single, extremely large pear-shaped gallstone. Classical cholecystectomy was carried out. Histological examination of the gallbladder showed acute cholecystitis with no sign of malignant neoplasia. What type of gallstone is considered to be more common in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pigmented This patient is from Delhi; in Asia 80% of gall stones are pigment stones. Pigmented stones contain < 20% cholesterol and are dark because of calcium bilirubin. Black and brown pigment stones have little in common and should be considered separate entities.

Highyeild:

Pigmented stones are gallstones composed of different pigments. Black stones are insoluble bilirubin pigment polymer mixed with calcium phosphate and calcium bicarbonate. Predisposing factors for black stones include hemolytic disorders, mechanical prosthetic heart valves, cirrhosis, Gilbert's syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and ileal disease or resection. Brown pigment stones contain calcium bilirubin, palmitate, stearate, and cholesterol. Brownstones are typically found in Asia and are rare in the gallbladder. Brownstones are formed in the bile duct and are related to bile stasis and infection. Gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli and Klebsiella secrete beta-glucuronidase, which deconjugates soluble conjugated bilirubin. Free unconjugated bilirubin precipitates and combines with calcium and bile to form brown pigment stones. Stones can form whenever static foreign bodies are present in the bile duct, such as stents or parasites such as Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Cholesterol or mixed stones contain 51–99% pure cholesterol plus an admixture of calcium salts, bile acids, pigments, and phospholipids. Option: C. Pure cholesterol stones are uncommon and account for < 10% of all stones. Option: D. Brownstones are pigmented stones formed either in the gallbladder or in the bile ducts secondary to bacterial infection and bile stasis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man complained of abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound indicated acute cholecystitis and a single, extremely large pear-shaped gallstone. Classical cholecystectomy was carried out. Histological examination of the gallbladder showed acute cholecystitis with no sign of malignant neoplasia. What type of gallstone is considered to be rare in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholesterol Pure cholesterol stones are uncommon and account for <10% of all stones. They usually occur as a single large stone with a smooth surface. Most cholesterol stones are mixed but are at least 70% cholesterol by weight in addition to variable amounts of bile pigments and calcium.

Highyeild:

Cholesterol Stones Cholesterol is insoluble in water, a major bile constituent (85-95%) . Bile acids and phospholipids in bile keep cholesterol in solution by forming micelles. When excess cholesterol is relative to bile acids and phospholipids, cholesterol can form crystals, and bile becomes lithogenic or supersaturated . Factors contributing to gallstone formation include lithogenic bile, nucleation, and stasis or gallbladder hypomotility. Cholesterol gallstones are made up of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Cholesterol or mixed stones contain 51–99% pure cholesterol plus an admixture of calcium salts, bile acids, pigments, and phospholipids. The Most common gallstone is Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. Option: B. 80% of gall stones are pigment stones in Asia. Pigmented stones contain < 20% cholesterol and are dark because of calcium bilirubin. Black and brown pigment stones have little in common and should be considered separate entities. Option: D. Brownstones are pigmented stones formed either in the gallbladder or in the bile ducts secondary to bacterial infection and bile stasis.

Extraedge:

Conditions associated with impaired gallbladder emptying, such as prolonged fasting, total parenteral nutrition vagotomy, and somatostatin analogues, can increase the risk of stone formation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was admitted with a 2-day history of progressive increasing abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant with the radiation of pain to the epigastric area. The patient also had nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. On examination, she was hemodynamically stable and was not febrile. She had no jaundice, and the patient had upper quadrant tenderness exacerbated during inspiration by the examiner’s right subcoastal palpation. Abdominal sonography was indicative of acute cholecystitis. Which sign is found to be positive in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Murphy’s sign Murphy’s sign - In the acute phase, the patient may have right upper quadrant tenderness exacerbated during inspiration by the examiner’s right subcostal palpation. A positive Murphy’s sign suggests acute inflammation and may be associated with leukocytosis and moderately elevated liver function tests. Murphy’s sign can be elicited both in supine and sitting position.

Highyeild:

Acute cholecystitis causes tenderness in the right upper quadrant . Murphy's sign , where tenderness is exacerbated during inspiration by palpation in the right sub-costal region, is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis. In some cases, a mass may become palpable due to the omentum walls of an inflamed gallbladder. If the inflammation does not subside, the gallbladder may develop empyema, and the wall may become necrotic and perforate, causing localized peritonitis . Complete obstruction of the cystic duct can occur, leading to reabsorption of bile salts by the gallbladder epithelium and secretion of uninfected mucus, resulting in a gallbladder mucocele .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A palpable, non-tender gallbladder is called a Courvoisier’s sign. Suppose the gallbladder is palpable in a jaundiced patient. In that case, it is unlikely to be due to gallstones because stones would have given rise to chronic inflammation and, subsequently, fibrosis of the gallbladder, rendering it incapable of dilatation. Option: C. Reynold’s pentad is a collection of signs and symptoms suggesting the diagnosis of obstructive ascending cholangitis, a serious infection of the biliary system. It is a combination of Charcot's triad (right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever) with shock (low blood pressure, tachycardia) and an altered mental status. Option: D. Boas sign is a clinical sign that is defined as hyperesthesia felt by the patient to light touch in the right lower scapular region or the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It is classically seen in patients with acute cholecystitis

A plain abdominal x-ray was obtained, which revealed a radio-dense mass in the right upper quadrant. The patient was diagnosed with a calcified gallstone. Predisposing factors for black stones include hemolytic disorders, mechanical prosthetic heart valves, cirrhosis, Gilbert's syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and ileal disease or resection. Brownstones are pigmented stones formed either in the gallbladder or in the bile ducts secondary to bacterial infection and bile stasis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old gentleman presented with four days of right upper quadrant abdominal pain with nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. On examination, Murphy’s sign was found to be positive. The patient was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis. Which of the following is considered a standard diagnostic test for gall stones?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

USG An abdominal ultrasound is the standard diagnostic test for gallstones as it is non- Ultrasound will show stones in the gallbladder with sensitivity and specificity of > 90%.

Highyeild:

The diagnosis of symptomatic cholelithiasis or chronic cholecystitis requires the presence of typical symptoms and the identification of stones through diagnostic imaging. Abdominal ultrasound is the standard diagnostic test for gallstones due to its high sensitivity and non-invasive nature. Gallstones can also be identified on abdominal CT scans as part of a broader workup for abdominal pain. Still, intervention should only be considered if the patient has typical symptoms. If gallstones are incidentally diagnosed in patients without symptoms, they should be left alone. Some patients may experience typical attacks of biliary pain but have no evidence of stones on ultrasound yet have sludge in the gallbladder. In such cases, cholecystectomy is necessary.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Stones can be diagnosed incidentally on plain radiographs in patients without symptoms. The plain radiograph of the gallbladder will show radiopaque gallstones in 10% of patients, in contrast to renal stones, where 90 percent stones are radio-opaque Option: B . CT scan is inferior to ultrasonography in diagnosing gallstones but is similar in sensitivity for acute cholecystitis. Gallstones are occasionally identified on abdominal CT scans as part of a broader workup of abdominal pain. Option: D . The primary use of biliary scintigraphy is in diagnosing acute cholecystitis, which appears as a non-visualized gallbladder, with prompt filling of the common bile duct and duodenum. In atypical cases, a HIDA scan may demonstrate cystic duct obstruction, which definitively diagnoses acute cholecystitis.

Extraedge:

Cholesterolosis and adenomyomatosis can also cause biliary symptoms and may be detected through ultrasound or CT. Cholesterolosis is caused by the accumulation of cholesterol in macrophages in the gallbladder lamina propria, which produces a classic studded macroscopic appearance known as a " strawberry gallbladder. " Adenomyomatosis (cholecystitis glandular proliferations) is characterized by the ingrowth of mucosal glands into the muscle layer and the development of granulomatous polyps in the lumen at the fundus. The gallbladder wall is also thickened, and septae or criticisms may be present. Cholecystectomy is the treatment for symptomatic patients with cholesterols and adenomyomatosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presented a history of progressively increasing abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, associated with nausea and general weakness for two days. He had a history of type 2 diabetes & hypertension for five years and asymptomatic single giant gallstone for ten years. On examination, he was febrile but hemodynamically stable. He was not jaundiced. The abdomen was tender, particularly in the upper right quadrant, where the gallbladder was palpable, with a positive Murphy's sign. Abdominal ultrasound demonstrated a thickened gallbladder wall and a single giant pear-shaped gallstone (estimated initially to be approximately 17 cm long × 10 cm at its maximum width and 5 cm at its minimum width). What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholecystectomy For patients with symptomatic gallstones, cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice if there are no medical contraindications. (Prophylactic cholecystectomy may be considered for diabetic patients with asymptomatic gallstones)- No!!!. Diabetes is no longer an indication of prophylactic cholecystectomy!

Highyeild:

Asymptomatic gallstones do not usually require intervention. Prophylactic cholecystectomy may be performed for asymptomatic cholelithiasis in certain situations Situations where prophylactic cholecystectomy may be considered include: Large (>3 cm) gallstones Choledocholithiasis Chronic hemolytic conditions (sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis) Gallbladder polyps >1 cm in diameter Suspicion/risk of malignancy (anomalous pancreatic ductal drainage) Calcification of the wall (porcelain gallbladder) Some ethnic groups or subjects living in areas with a high prevalence of gallbladder cancer associated with gallstones Transplant patients (during transplantation) Patients undergoing bariatric surgery For symptomatic gallstones, cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice if there are no medical contraindications Initial non-operative treatment for symptomatic gallstones involves four steps: Nil by mouth and intravenous fluid administration until pain resolve Analgesics Antibiotics (broad-spectrum antibiotics effective against Gram-negative aerobes are preferred) Subsequent management involves reintroducing oral fluids and a regular diet once physical signs of inflammation have subsided.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Observing patients with asymptomatic gallstones is considered safe. However, prophylactic cholecystectomy may be considered for diabetic patients, those with congenital hemolytic anemia, and those undergoing bariatric surgery for morbid obesity because it has been found that the risk of developing symptoms is increased in these groups. Option: C. A broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against gram-negative aerobes is most appropriate (e.g., cefazolin, cefuroxime, or ciprofloxacin) as a Non-operative treatment of acute cholecystitis. Option: D. Administration of analgesics as a Non-operative treatment of acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female presented with the acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, and intermittent vomiting. On water-soluble contrast follow-through examination, she showed total bowel obstruction due to a suspected gallstone at the level of proximal duodenum causing gastric outlet obstruction. Obstruction at this level is also called?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bouveret syndrome Bouveret syndrome is a rare form of gallstone ileus secondary to an acquired fistula between the gallbladder and the duodenum or stomach. Bouveret’s syndrome usually presents with non-specific symptoms, most commonly a triad of epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. It could also present with abdominal pain, distension, upper gastrointestinal bleeding, fever, weight loss, and anorexia.

Highyeild:

Bouveret's Syndrome is caused by a gallstone obstructing the duodenum, typically in the bulb area. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Diagnosis can be made through imaging studies such as CT scans or X-rays. Treatment options include duodenostomy and pyloroplasty . Duodenostomy involves creating an opening in the duodenum to bypass the obstruction, while pyloroplasty involves widening the opening between the stomach and small intestine. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to avoid complications such as bowel perforation and infection.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Mirizzi’s syndrome: The impaction of a large stone in the neck of the gallbladder obstructing the level of the confluence of the cystic duct and common hepatic duct is called Mirizzi’s syndrome. Option: C. Murphy’s sign - In the acute phase, the patient may have right upper quadrant tenderness exacerbated during inspiration by the examiner’s right subcostal palpation. A positive Murphy’s sign suggests acute inflammation and may be associated with leukocytosis and moderately elevated liver function tests. Option: D. Courvoiser’s sign : A palpable, non-tender gallbladder is called Courvoisier’s sign. Suppose the gallbladder is palpable in a jaundiced patient. In that case, it is unlikely to be due to gallstones because stones would have given rise to chronic inflammation and, subsequently, fibrosis of the gallbladder, rendering it incapable of dilatation.

questions.text: A 42 year old female presented with the complaints of sudden cramping, epigastric pain, and nausea two months following endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), where three gallstones were removed from the common bile ducts. Ultrasound showed a non-inflamed gallbladder with a large stone and a dilated common bile duct. A cholecystoduodenal fistula was also present. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing gallstone ileus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT Gallstone ileus presents with symptoms such as constipation, nausea, and abdominal pain. Plain films may not always identify a radiolucent stone, while ultrasound can be limited by extensive bowel gas. CT is highly sensitive and specific for identifying gallstone ileus and can determine the location of the obstruction. Management of gallstone ileus involves relieving the intestinal obstruction and removing the stone. Endoscopic retrieval may be effective for proximal obstructions in the stomach or duodenum. Surgical enterolithotomy , either laparoscopically or open, may be necessary for more distal stones.

Highyeild:

Gallstone ileus presents with symptoms such as constipation, nausea, and abdominal pain. Plain films may not always identify a radiolucent stone, while ultrasound can be limited by extensive bowel gas. CT is highly sensitive and specific for identifying gallstone ileus and can determine the location of the obstruction. Management of gallstone ileus involves relieving the intestinal obstruction and removing the stone. Endoscopic retrieval may be effective for proximal obstructions in the stomach or duodenum. Surgical enterolithotomy , either laparoscopically or open, may be necessary for more distal stones.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Ultrasound evaluation for gallstone ileus may be limited by extensive bowel gas and hence not considered the investigation of choice. Option: C. Plain films may show an obstructive bowel gas pattern but may fail to identify a radiolucent stone in the case of gallstone ileus and hence not considered the investigation of choice. Option: D. None of the above can be the correct answer.

Extraedge:

Enterolithotomy involves removing the stone through an enterotomy that is then repaired or resected depending on size. Stones that have passed the ileocecal valve will likely pass without further intervention. Pursuing cholecystectomy and choledochoenteric fistula closure at the time of enterolithotomy or addressing it later is debated but should be considered to reduce the risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presented with a history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain for 3 days. The pain was constant, cramping, non-radiating, and associated with vomiting and abdominal distension. Computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrated multiple loops of moderated dilated small bowel, and the patient was diagnosed with gallstone ileus. Which of the following is a characteristic radiological sign of gallstone ileus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rigler’s triad The characteristic radiological sign of gallstone ileus is Rigler’s triad, comprising: small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and an atypical mineral shadow on radiographs of the abdomen.

Highyeild:

Gallstone ileus can be diagnosed through the presence of Rigler's triad on radiographs of the abdomen Rigler's triad is composed of small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and an unusual mineral shadow If two of these signs are present , it is considered pathognomonic of gallstone ileus and can be seen in 40-50% of cases Pneumobilia is a common finding after endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Charcot’s triad is the presence of classic symptoms of fever, epigastric or right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice in Cholangitis. Option: C. The “ Mercedes-Benz sign ” describes a triradiate pattern of nitrogen gas within gallstones initially described on an abdominal radiograph in cases of calculus cholecystitis. Option: D. The Mercedes Benz sign, also known as the seagull sign, refers to the typical triradiate pattern on imaging performed for diagnosing gallstones.

Extraedge:

The treatment for gallstone ileus typically involves laparotomy The stone should be milked proximally away from the site of impaction It may be possible to crush the stone within the bowel lumen, but if not, the intestine should be opened at this point to remove the gallstone If the gallstone is faceted, a careful check for other enteric stones should be made The region of the gallbladder should not be explored.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with complaints of nausea, recurrent vomiting, and colicky abdominal pain for five days. Physical examination revealed a non-tender abdomen with active bowel sounds. The abdominal radiograph demonstrated the presence of a round hyperdense mass with calcified margins in the right lower quadrant and enlarged loops of the small bowel. CT scan of the abdomen showed pneumobilia, a calcified intraluminal mass impacted in the terminal ileum, and dilated upstream loops of small intestine. These findings were diagnostic for gallstone ileus. What is the most common site of impaction of gallstone ileus?

options.label: A
options.text: About 60 cm proximal to the ileocaecal valve

options.label: B
options.text: About 30 cm distal to the ileocaecal valve

options.label: C
options.text: About 30 cm proximal to the ileocaecal valve.

options.label: D
options.text: About 60 cm distal to the ileocaecal valve

questions.correct_answer: A. About 60 cm proximal to the ileocaecal valve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

About 60 cm proximal to the ileocaecal valve Classically, the impaction is about 60 cm proximal to the ileocaecal valve in gallstone ileus. This type of bolus obstruction tends to occur in the elderly secondary to erosion of a large gallstone directly through the gall bladder into the duodenum. The patient may have recurrent attacks as the obstruction is frequently incomplete or relapsing due to a ball-valve effect .

Highyeild:

Gallstone ileus Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis where gallstones are impacted in the GI tract. It is more common in elderly individuals and women. Acute cholecystitis can lead to erosion of inflamed tissues, resulting in a cholecystointestinal fistula . Small gallstones usually pass through the intestines on their own. Still, gallstones 2-5 cm in size may become stuck , particularly at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve, due to the narrow lumen and less active peristalsis. Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of partial or complete gastrointestinal obstruction, dehydration, abdominal distension, tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice. Diagnostic methods include plain abdominal radiograph, CT, and USG.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Impaction about 30 cm distal to the ileocaecal valve is not the correct option. Option: C. Impaction about 30 cm proximal to the ileocaecal valve is not the correct option. Option: D. Impaction about 60 cm distal to the ileocaecal valve is not the correct option.

Extraedge:

CT is considered superior to plain radiographs or USG, with a sensitivity of up to 93%. The most common surgical procedure for gallstone ileus is enterolithotomy , where a longitudinal incision is made on the antimesenteric border proximal to the site of gallstone impaction. A cholecystoenteric fistula should only be resected if the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and nausea. Physical examination revealed tenderness at the right upper quadrant and a positive Murphy sign. A diagnosis of cholecystitis with cholecystoenteric fistula was made by endoscopy and computed tomography. What is the most common site of the formation of cholecystoenteric fistula?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenum Perforation in acute cholecystitis is usually contained in the subhepatic space by the omentum and adjacent organs. However, free perforation with peritonitis, intrahepatic perforation with intrahepatic abscesses, and perforation into adjacent organs like the duodenum or colon with cholecystoenteric fistula have been described.

Highyeild:

Gangrenous cholecystitis can lead to severe infections with potential complications. Complications include abscess or perforation. Perforations are typically contained in the subhepatic space by nearby organs and the omentum . However, free perforation with peritonitis , intrahepatic perforation with intrahepatic abscesses , and perforation into adjacent organs such as the duodenum or colon with cholecystoenteric fistula may occur.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Pylorus is not the most common site for forming cholecystoenteric fistula. Option: C. The terminal ileum is the most common site of the formation of cholecystoenteric fistula. Option: D. Pancreas is not the most common site of the formation of cholecystoenteric fistula.

Extraedge:

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a condition where gas-forming organisms are present in the secondary bacterial infection, leading to gas in the gallbladder lumen and wall on abdominal radiographs and CT scans.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female underwent a laproscopic cholecystectomy as the result of biliary colic. Analysis of the gall bladder revealed signs of biliary infection. Which of the following is the most common causative organism of biliary infection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E.coli The most common types of bacteria found in biliary infections are Enterobacteriaceae, such as Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, and Enterobacter, followed by Enterococcus spp.

Highyeild:

The biliary tree is not sterile since it connects to the duodenum. Infection in the absence of obstruction is rare due to a low bacterial load and bile flow. Stones or obstruction can increase the likelihood of bacterial infection. Enterobacteriaceae , such as Escherichia coli , Klebsiella , and Enterobacter , are the most common bacteria found in biliary infections, followed by Enterococcus spp . Prophylactic antibiotics should be used for most patients undergoing interventions in the biliary tree, such as ERCP or PTC. A first- or second-generation cephalosporin or fluoroquinolone should cover the most common bacterial species.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Salmonella typhi or typhimurium can infect the gallbladder, and chronic cholecystitis is more common. Option: C. Streptococcus is not the most common causative organism of biliary infection. Option: D. Enterococcus is not the most common causative organism of biliary infection.

Extraedge:

Antibiotic prophylaxis is unnecessary for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy for biliary colic. Antibiotics should be used for any patient with suspected or documented infection of the biliary tree, such as acute cholecystitis or ascending cholangitis. Antibiotics should be chosen to cover gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and nausea and was diagnosed with cholecystoenteric fistula following cholecystitis. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for cholecystoenteric fistula?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRCP MR cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is non-invasive and delineates the siteof ductal disruption, especially upstream, that is not visible on ERCP and is the investigation of choice for cholecystoenteric fistula. It is T2 MRI.

Highyeild:

MRCP is a susceptible and specific diagnostic tool in detecting CBD stones. Sensitivity and specificity rates of MRCP exceed 90% and 99% , respectively. MRCP is a non-invasive test and cannot be used to treat CBD stones. Additional procedures such as ERCP or CBD exploration may be required following diagnosis. Preoperative MRCP can be used to determine whether preoperative ERCP is necessary.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The widespread availability of ultrasound and MRCP has reduced its diagnostic use, but ERCP still has an important role in assessing the patient with obstructive jaundice for determining the cause and level of obstruction. Option: C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is an invasive technique useful in studying anatomy and biliary strictures. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is rarely needed in patients with common bile duct stones but can be performed for diagnostic and therapeutic reasons in patients with contraindications to endoscopic or surgical approaches. Option: D. Transabdominal ultrasonography (US) is the initial imaging modality for gallstones.

questions.text: A 38 year-old female presented with the chief complaints of severe Epigastrium pain for three days. The pain was Intermittent and radiating to the back and was associated with Dysphagia, nausea, and vomiting. On physical examination, there was tenderness at the epigastrium and Right Upper Quadrant with no rebound tenderness, guarding, or Normoactive bowel sound. Murphy’s sign was positive. A provisional diagnosis of Acute Cholecystitis was made. Which of the following is a condition under Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for Grade III acute cholecystitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased level of consciousness Grade III (severe) acute cholecystitis is associated with Neurological dysfunction. Other dysfunctions include - Cardiovascular dysfunction with Hypertension requiring treatment with dopamine ≤ 5 μg/kg/min or any dose of norepinephrine (noradrenaline), Respiratory dysfunction with PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 300, Renal dysfunction with Oliguria and creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL.

Highyeild:

Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for severity grading of acute cholecystitis: Grade III (severe) acute cholecystitis: Associated with dysfunction of any one of the following organs/systems: Cardiovascular dysfunction-Hypertension requiring treatment with dopamine ≤5µg/kg/min, or any dose of norepinephrine (noradrenaline) Neurological dysfunction-Decreased level of consciousness. Respiratory dysfunction PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300. Renal dysfunction Oliguria; creatinine >2.0mg/dL Hepatic dysfunction Prothrombin time (PT-INR) >1.5 Hematological dysfunction-Platelet count <100000/mm3 Grade II (moderate) acute cholecystitis: Associated with any one of the following conditions: Elevated white cell count (>18000/mm3) Palpable tender mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant Duration of complaints >72 hours Marked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic abscess, hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis) Grade I (mild) acute cholecystitis: Grade I can also be defined as acute cholecystitis in a healthy person with no organ dysfunction and mild inflammatory changes in the gallbladder, making cholecystectomy a safe and low-risk operative procedure. Does not meet the criteria of grade II or grade III acute cholecystitis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Duration of complaints > 72 hours is a condition under Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for Grade II acute cholecystitis. Option: C. Platelet count < 100 000/mm3 is a condition under Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for Grade III acute cholecystitis. Option: D. Prothrombin time (PT-INR) > 1.5 is a condition under Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for Grade III acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy in patients with gall stones?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Refractory coagulopathy Absolute contraindications to laparoscopic cholecystectomy include hemodynamic instability, uncontrolled coagulopathy, frank peritonitis, and suspicion of malignancy.

Highyeild:

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is generally safe and has few absolute contraindications. Absolute contraindications include hemodynamic instability, uncontrolled coagulopathy, or frank peritonitis. Patients with severe obstructive pulmonary disease or congestive heart failure may not tolerate the increased intraabdominal pressures of pneumoperitoneum with carbon dioxide and may require an open cholecystectomy. Previously thought to be relative contraindications, conditions such as acute cholecystitis, gangrene and empyema of the gallbladder, biliary-enteric fistulae, obesity, pregnancy, ventriculoperitoneal shunts, cirrhosis, and previous upper abdominal procedures are now considered risk factors for a potentially difficult cholecystectomy, but they do not necessarily preclude laparoscopy. Conversion to an open operation should always remain an option and not be considered a failure.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. COPD is a relative contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Option: B . Liver Cirrhosis is a relative contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Option: C. Cholangitis is a relative contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Extraedge:

In the elective setting, conversion to an open procedure is needed in about 5% of patients. Emergent procedures or patients with complicated gallstone disease can be more challenging, and the incidence of conversion is between 10% and 30%. It is important to discuss the possibility of conversion to open with the patient before surgery.

questions.text: Identify the characteristic radiological sign in the image
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rigler's triad The characteristic radiological sign of gallstone ileus is Rigler’s triad, comprising: small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and an atypical mineral shadow on radiographs of the abdomen. Image showing Rigler’s Sign And Rigler’s Traid.

Highyeild:

Gallstone ileus can be diagnosed through the presence of Rigler's triad on radiographs of the abdomen Rigler's triad is composed of small bowel obstruction, pneumonia, and an unusual mineral shadow If two of these signs are present , it is considered pathognomonic of gallstone ileus and can be seen in 40-50% of cases Pneumobilia is a common finding after endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Charcot’s triad is the presence of classic symptoms of fever, epigastric or right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice in Cholangitis. Option: C. The “Mercedes-Benz sign” describes a triradiate pattern of nitrogen gas within gallstones initially described on an abdominal radiograph in cases of calculus cholecystitis. Option: D. The Mercedes Benz sign, also known as the seagull sign, refers to the typical triradiate pattern seen on imaging performed for diagnosing gallstones.

Extraedge:

The treatment for gallstone ileus typically involves laparotomy The stone should be milked proximally away from the site of impaction It may be possible to crush the stone within the bowel lumen, but if not, the intestine should be opened at this point to remove the gallstone If the gallstone is faceted, a careful check for other enteric stones should be made The region of the gallbladder should not be explored.
